newsitem.title: FRANCE: Renault unions slam dealer plan.
newsitem.headline: Renault unions slam dealer plan.

text.p: Unions at French carmaker Renault SA on Friday said they oppose the company's plan to form a subsidiary to run its 77 French dealerships and bring the 10,000 staff under the same collective agreement.

"All the trade unions -- the CGT, CFDT, CGC, FO, CFTC and CSL -- reject the plan to group the dealers into a subsidiary and demand that it be scrapped," the CGT said in a statement issued after a staff council meeting, during which the company presented the plan.
"That represents the near totality of the staff in opposition to the plan," it said.
Renault announced plans earlier this month to form the subsidiary in July.

Its 77 French dealerships generated 26 percent of its sales in France last year. Fifty-three of the dealerships are company branches, employing 8,600 staff covered by the metallurgical collective agreement. They had a combined operating loss of 247 million francs last year.
The other 24 dealerships are structured as corporate subsidiaries, and their 1,400 workers are covered by the automotive services collective agreement.
The subsidiaries traditionally perform better than the branches, but Renault has not disclosed their 1996 results.
The entire Renault group posted a 5.25 billion franc loss for 1996, including 3.9 billion in charges, and has embarked on aggressive cost-cutting moves.
